import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
source.34088fea:
data = pd.read_csv('../input/student-result/4 Sem SEE Result.csv')
data.head()

source.c0884567:
y = ['18MA401','18CS402','18CS403','18CS404','18CS405','18IC406','18CS407']
width = [data['18MA401'].mean(),data['18CS402'].mean(),data['18CS403'].mean(),data['18CS404'].mean(),data['18CS405'].mean(),data['18IC406'].mean(),data['18CS407'].mean()]

plt.figure(figsize = (18,5))
plt.barh(y = y, width = width)
plt.title('Average Scores')
plt.xlabel('Score')
plt.ylabel('Subjects')
for i,v in enumerate(width):
    plt.text(v, i, " "+str(round(v,2)), color='blue', va='center', fontweight='bold')
plt.show()
# can use describe() function but diagram/figure gives more weitiage while presentating than numeorus words.
source.59f5733d:
topper = data[(data['Percentage'] >= 95)]
top_85 = data[(data['Percentage'] < 95) & (data['Percentage'] >= 85)]
top_75 = data[(data['Percentage'] < 85) & (data['Percentage'] >= 75)]
top_65 = data[(data['Percentage'] < 75) & (data['Percentage'] >= 65)]
top_55 = data[(data['Percentage'] < 65) & (data['Percentage'] >= 55)]
top_45 = data[(data['Percentage'] < 55) & (data['Percentage'] >= 45)]
source.bdc1b9a6:
# Plotting graphs for marks range. 
y = ['More Than 95','95 & 85','85 & 75','75 & 65','65 & 55','55 & 45']
width = [topper['USN'].count(),top_85['USN'].count(),top_75['USN'].count(),top_65['USN'].count(),top_55['USN'].count(),top_45['USN'].count()]

plt.figure(figsize = (20,3))
plt.barh(y = y, width = width)
plt.title('Count Of Students In Different Marks Range')
plt.xlabel('Student Count')
plt.ylabel('Categories Range')
for i,v in enumerate(width):
    plt.text(v, i, " "+str(round(v,2)), color='blue', va='center', fontweight='bold')
plt.show()
